paragraphs.body: Body markings are widely used throughout the ${link_0}, and are applied for a variety of purposes. Some, such as makeup and other cosmetics, are used for statements of beauty or ${link_1} and are not unique to any one group. Other markings serve purposes of identification—usually with a specific group or nation—and carry a deeper level of cultural symbolism.
paragraphs.text: Body markings are widely used throughout the World of Avatar, and are applied for a variety of purposes. Some, such as makeup and other cosmetics, are used for statements of beauty or fashion and are not unique to any one group. Other markings serve purposes of identification—usually with a specific group or nation—and carry a deeper level of cultural symbolism.

paragraphs.body: ${link_0} had a series of tattoos around his body.
paragraphs.text: Aang had a series of tattoos around his body.

paragraphs.body: Upon reaching the level of master, ${link_0} are tattooed with five light blue arrows: one extending from the base of the spine to the forehead, one for each arm pointing to the hands, and likewise for the legs and feet. This pattern is an emulation of the ${link_1}'s natural markings, as they were the first airbenders. Unlike most master airbenders who gain their status later in life, ${link_2} ${link_3} received his tattoos when he was only twelve, following his invention of the ${link_4}. This made him the youngest known airbending master until his granddaughter ${link_5} received her tattoos at the age of eleven in 171 ${link_6}.
paragraphs.text: Upon reaching the level of master, airbenders are tattooed with five light blue arrows: one extending from the base of the spine to the forehead, one for each arm pointing to the hands, and likewise for the legs and feet. This pattern is an emulation of the flying bison's natural markings, as they were the first airbenders. Unlike most master airbenders who gain their status later in life, Avatar Aang received his tattoos when he was only twelve, following his invention of the air scooter. This made him the youngest known airbending master until his granddaughter Jinora received her tattoos at the age of eleven in 171 AG.

paragraphs.body: As they run along ${link_0} paths, the tattoos of an ${link_1} Avatar will glow when they enter the ${link_2}.[source?] If the Avatar's body has received a severe injury on a tattooed area, leaving a scar deeper than the tattoo, then that particular spot will not glow.
paragraphs.text: As they run along chi paths, the tattoos of an Air Nomad Avatar will glow when they enter the Avatar State.[source?] If the Avatar's body has received a severe injury on a tattooed area, leaving a scar deeper than the tattoo, then that particular spot will not glow.

paragraphs.body: The earliest known ancestors of the Air Nomads lived on top of the air ${link_0} during the ${link_1} and had similar tattoos along their bodies, though the ends bore an upside down "T" with a dot beneath it and they were applied even to children. As these people only received the power to control air while out of the city, the tattoo was not associated with airbending mastery.
paragraphs.text: The earliest known ancestors of the Air Nomads lived on top of the air lion turtle during the era of Raava and had similar tattoos along their bodies, though the ends bore an upside down "T" with a dot beneath it and they were applied even to children. As these people only received the power to control air while out of the city, the tattoo was not associated with airbending mastery.

paragraphs.body: The Mark of the Brave is moon-shaped.
paragraphs.text: The Mark of the Brave is moon-shaped.

paragraphs.body: The Mark of the Brave is a crescent-shaped mark that resembles the moon and is given for "inspirational displays of courage." During Sokka's rite of passage, Katara held the position of bravery as she needed to secure the boat's mainsail and thus prevail against the brutal winds. Following her successful completion of the ritual, Bato bestowed the Mark of the Brave upon her.
paragraphs.text: The Mark of the Brave is a crescent-shaped mark that resembles the moon and is given for "inspirational displays of courage." During Sokka's rite of passage, Katara held the position of bravery as she needed to secure the boat's mainsail and thus prevail against the brutal winds. Following her successful completion of the ritual, Bato bestowed the Mark of the Brave upon her.

paragraphs.body: The Mark of the Trusted is a horizontal arc given to outsiders who are able to prove themselves worthy of the Water Tribe's trust. For example, while ${link_0}, Aang controlled the jib of his group's cutter to successfully navigate the rocky waters; this position related to trust, as without a steady hand, the whole crew would go down.
paragraphs.text: The Mark of the Trusted is a horizontal arc given to outsiders who are able to prove themselves worthy of the Water Tribe's trust. For example, while ice dodging, Aang controlled the jib of his group's cutter to successfully navigate the rocky waters; this position related to trust, as without a steady hand, the whole crew would go down.

paragraphs.body: The Mark of the Wise also features an arc, though with a small black dot under it.
paragraphs.text: The Mark of the Wise also features an arc, though with a small black dot under it.

paragraphs.body: The Mark of the Wise is a horizontal arc above a dot and is given for deft decision-making and the ability to maintain leadership under pressure. Hakoda received this mark, and years later, so did his son, Sokka, for steering the boat as well as for leading Aang and Katara wisely through the rough waters by instructing them on what to do.
paragraphs.text: The Mark of the Wise is a horizontal arc above a dot and is given for deft decision-making and the ability to maintain leadership under pressure. Hakoda received this mark, and years later, so did his son, Sokka, for steering the boat as well as for leading Aang and Katara wisely through the rough waters by instructing them on what to do.

paragraphs.body: Water Tribe Warriors, elite nonbending fighters of both the ${link_0} and ${link_1}, wear full-face war paint when going into battle, colored black, gray, and white. In addition to intimidating opponnents, this disguise helps the warriors blend into the icy landscape of their polar homes. In the Northern Water Tribe, it is also customary for the chief to ceremonially apply three red markings to the forehead of chosen warriors departing on a dangerous mission.
paragraphs.text: Water Tribe Warriors, elite nonbending fighters of both the Northern and Southern Water Tribes, wear full-face war paint when going into battle, colored black, gray, and white. In addition to intimidating opponnents, this disguise helps the warriors blend into the icy landscape of their polar homes. In the Northern Water Tribe, it is also customary for the chief to ceremonially apply three red markings to the forehead of chosen warriors departing on a dangerous mission.

paragraphs.body: During ${link_0}, certain fighters were tattooed or wore body paint or make-up: ${link_1} possessed a tattoo of a ${link_2} on his back, a self-proclamation of his earthbending prowess, and ${link_3}'s face was painted as part of his fighting persona.
paragraphs.text: During Earth Rumble VI, certain fighters were tattooed or wore body paint or make-up: The Boulder possessed a tattoo of a badgermole on his back, a self-proclamation of his earthbending prowess, and Headhunter's face was painted as part of his fighting persona.

paragraphs.body: ${link_0}'s trademark style of face paint was later used by the ${link_1}.
paragraphs.text: Kyoshi's trademark style of face paint was later used by the Kyoshi Warriors.

paragraphs.body: The all-female ${link_0} have a strict garb which is worn both in battle and during training. A key feature of this uniform is facial paint, consisting of a white foundation with accents in red and black, meant to strike fear into the hearts of the warriors' opponents. Along with the armor and weapons of the uniform, this paint was designed to resemble the attire of Avatar ${link_1}.
paragraphs.text: The all-female Kyoshi Warriors have a strict garb which is worn both in battle and during training. A key feature of this uniform is facial paint, consisting of a white foundation with accents in red and black, meant to strike fear into the hearts of the warriors' opponents. Along with the armor and weapons of the uniform, this paint was designed to resemble the attire of Avatar Kyoshi.

paragraphs.body: All members of the ${link_0}, an ancient ${link_1} civilization predating the modern-day ${link_2}, bore two red markings on their cheeks, foreheads, noses, and various other spots on their faces, which they kept on throughout several different occasions. The sole known exception to this is the ${link_3}, who only wore red war paint from below the eye area, up into his face, which was bordered by a level of white face paint.
paragraphs.text: All members of the Sun Warriors, an ancient firebending civilization predating the modern-day Fire Nation, bore two red markings on their cheeks, foreheads, noses, and various other spots on their faces, which they kept on throughout several different occasions. The sole known exception to this is the Sun Warrior chief, who only wore red war paint from below the eye area, up into his face, which was bordered by a level of white face paint.

paragraphs.body: ${link_0}' third eye tattoo focusses their combustion beam.
paragraphs.text: Combustionbenders' third eye tattoo focusses their combustion beam.

paragraphs.body: ${link_0}, firebenders with the rare ability to shoot an explosive beam of energy from their forehead, have a tattoo of an eye on the spot from where their attack is released. Although this tattoo marks the bender's point of power, it also marks their weak spot; by striking this spot or continuously blocking it, the bender's flow of chi can be interrupted, preventing them from using their abilities.
paragraphs.text: Combustionbenders, firebenders with the rare ability to shoot an explosive beam of energy from their forehead, have a tattoo of an eye on the spot from where their attack is released. Although this tattoo marks the bender's point of power, it also marks their weak spot; by striking this spot or continuously blocking it, the bender's flow of chi can be interrupted, preventing them from using their abilities.

paragraphs.body: Although the main feature of this tattoo is a red eye positioned vertically, other features of the design can vary; while ${link_0} and ${link_1} both had three pinkish, horizontal lines surrounding their third eye, his were thick and straight, while hers were more refined and curvilinear.
paragraphs.text: Although the main feature of this tattoo is a red eye positioned vertically, other features of the design can vary; while Combustion Man and P'Li both had three pinkish, horizontal lines surrounding their third eye, his were thick and straight, while hers were more refined and curvilinear.

paragraphs.body: ${link_0}'s face shows the tattoos of the ${link_1}.
paragraphs.text: Vachir's face shows the tattoos of the Yuyan Archers.

paragraphs.body: The elite marksmen of the ${link_0} bear dark red tattoos that run as a strip across their eyes, the ends of which flare out over the forehead and cheeks while the center narrows over the bridge of the nose. The placement of their tattoos symbolizes the importance of sight in their deadly skill. Similar in principle to the tattoos of master airbenders, the tattoos of the Yuyan Archers identify them as part of an elite group.
paragraphs.text: The elite marksmen of the Yuyan Archers bear dark red tattoos that run as a strip across their eyes, the ends of which flare out over the forehead and cheeks while the center narrows over the bridge of the nose. The placement of their tattoos symbolizes the importance of sight in their deadly skill. Similar in principle to the tattoos of master airbenders, the tattoos of the Yuyan Archers identify them as part of an elite group.

paragraphs.body: In the ${link_0} chapter of the ${link_1}, the girls took mastering a kind of faux airbending very seriously and even began tattooing themselves in a way similar to master airbenders. However, Avatar Aang saw the tattoos as disgracing his culture, so as he began to teach the club members about his culture and renamed the fan club the "${link_2}", the practice of tattooing was discontinued.
paragraphs.text: In the Yu Dao chapter of the Official Avatar Aang Fan Club, the girls took mastering a kind of faux airbending very seriously and even began tattooing themselves in a way similar to master airbenders. However, Avatar Aang saw the tattoos as disgracing his culture, so as he began to teach the club members about his culture and renamed the fan club the "Air Acolytes", the practice of tattooing was discontinued.

paragraphs.body: A ${link_0}'s tattoo featured a snake on his upper chest which wrapped around his right arm.
paragraphs.text: A Chin Village prisoner's tattoo featured a snake on his upper chest which wrapped around his right arm.

paragraphs.body: Other groups and individuals throughout the ${link_0} also bear tattoos. For the most part, these appear to be purely ornamental and do not carry any significant meaning. The bounty hunter ${link_1}, for instance, had a red tattoo depicting a coiled snake on each shoulder.
paragraphs.text: Other groups and individuals throughout the four nations also bear tattoos. For the most part, these appear to be purely ornamental and do not carry any significant meaning. The bounty hunter June, for instance, had a red tattoo depicting a coiled snake on each shoulder.

paragraphs.body: While not an official designation of their lifestyle, tattoos are common among criminals or people who participate in otherwise less-than-legal activities. The pirates that attacked Aang, and later ${link_0}, as well as the criminals imprisoned in ${link_1}, sported tattoos. One of the ${link_2} in Chin Village even noted that tattoos would help one fit in among other criminals. Certain prisoners in the ${link_3} had tattoos, as did ${link_4}, a member of the ${link_5}.
paragraphs.text: While not an official designation of their lifestyle, tattoos are common among criminals or people who participate in otherwise less-than-legal activities. The pirates that attacked Aang, and later Zuko, as well as the criminals imprisoned in Chin Village, sported tattoos. One of the prisoners in Chin Village even noted that tattoos would help one fit in among other criminals. Certain prisoners in the Boiling Rock had tattoos, as did Ghazan, a member of the Red Lotus.

source.title: Body markings in the World of Avatar
